The image is a visual representation of a process, specifically a hiring process, depicted as a funnel chart. The chart is titled "The Pass Rates of Interviewing," which indicates that it is showing the percentage of candidates who pass each stage of the interview process. The stages are listed vertically along the left side of the funnel, starting from the top with "Application" and ending at the bottom with "Offer." Each stage is color-coded, with the colors corresponding to the legend on the right side of the image. The legend also includes the percentage of candidates who pass each stage, indicated by the color's shade.

Starting from the top, the application stage has a 100% pass rate, meaning all candidates who apply are considered. The pass rate then decreases as we move down the funnel. After the application, the next stage is the "Brief Interview by HR," which has a pass rate of 70%, with a range of 30% to 70%. This suggests that 30% of the candidates who apply pass the interview, while 70% do not. The next stage, "Testing," has a pass rate of 57%, with a range of 13% to 57%. This means that 13% of the candidates who passed the interview also passed the testing phase, while 57% did not. Following that, "Revealing some other information" has a pass rate of 38%, with a range of 19% to 38%. This indicates that 19% of those who passed testing also passed this stage, while 38% did not. Finally, the "Interview with the director" has a pass rate of 15%, with a range of 23% to 15%, and the "Offer" stage has a pass rate of 10%, with a range of 5% to 10%. This means that 23% of those who passed the interview with the director also passed the offer stage, while 10% did not.

The chart visually represents the decreasing number of candidates as they progress through each stage of the interview process, with the largest number of candidates at the application stage and the smallest at the offer stage.

question: Extract the text in the image
hpto1.1: [ABSTRACT] Incomplete information game (IIG) exists widely in real life, such as military resources allocation, commercial competition, social governance and so on. Because of the reward feedback in the game process, reinforcement learning (RL) is a promising technique for solving such complex problems. Meanwhile, it is critical in IIG to obtain valuable information by analyzing opponent's behaviors. Based on uncertainty modeling in IIG, this thesis proposes an RL algorithm with opponent models, in order to respond adaptively to different types of opponents. Theoretically, this thesis proposes three methods to measure uncertainty in IIG: utility fluctuation method, regret value method, and information entropy method, which will be applied to th proposed uncertainty-based RL algorithm.Multiple combinations of opponent models & decision networks are also applied to target different types of opponents. More specifically, three model selection methods are proposed: threshold scheduling method, learning scheduling method, and analysis scheduling method. In order to fully consider the uncertainty, this thesis innovatively adopts the Q-Learning algorithm based on the uncertainty in the decision network. A set of sub-networks for modelling opponents and model selection methods finally constitute the uncertainty- based RL algorithm with opponent models in this thesis.
